chapter.htmlHeader: What are the causes of infertility?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• In the UK [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013]:
    • The main causes of infertility are ovulatory disorders (25% of couples), tubal damage (20% of couples), male infertility (30% of couples), and uterine or peritoneal disorders (10% of couples). Gamete or embryo defects, uterine or endometrial factors, and pelvic conditions, such as endometriosis, may also be of significance.
    • There is no identifiable cause of infertility in about 25% of couples.
    • The presence of disorders in both the man and the woman has been reported in about 40% of infertile couples.
  • In women, the most common causes of infertility are ovulatory disorders, presenting as menstrual disturbances. Other causes and risk factors include tubal, uterine, and cervical factors; the use of certain drugs; stress; and lifestyle factors (such as smoking, obesity, and alcohol consumption) [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013]. See the section on Causes and risk factors of infertility in women for more information.
  • In men, no underlying cause for infertility is found in about 44% of cases (idiopathic male infertility). 
    • In these men [Jungwirth et al, 2012; EAU, 2016]:
      • There is no previous history of diseases affecting fertility, and physical findings, as well as endocrine, genetic, and biochemical laboratory testing (usually done in secondary care), are normal.
      • However, semen analysis might reveal a decreased number of spermatozoa (oligozoospermia), decreased sperm motility (asthenozoospermia), and many abnormal sperm on morphological examination (teratozoospermia). Oligospermia, asthenozoospermia, and teratozoospermia usually occur together and are described as the oligo-astheno-teratozoospermia syndrome.
    • Identifiable causes of infertility in men include primary spermatogenic disorders, genetic disorders, obstructive azoospermia, varicocele, hypogonadism, cryptorchidism (undescended testes), vasectomy, infection, stress, and lifestyle factors (such as smoking, obesity, and excessive alcohol consumption) [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013; EAU, 2016]. See the section on Causes and risk factors of infertility in men for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Causes of infertility in women
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ovulation disorders (present in about 25% of couples) are the most common causes of infertility in women.
    • The World Health Organization (WHO) categorizes ovulation disorders into three groups [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013]:
      • Group I ovulation disorders (also known as hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism) are caused by hypothalamic pituitary failure. They include conditions such as hypothalamic amenorrhea (which commonly develops as a result of low body weight or excessive exercise) and hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism (cause is unknown in most cases but may be congenital, for example when associated with anosmia [Kallmann syndrome]). About 10% of women with ovulation disorders have a group I ovulation disorder.  Women typically present with amenorrhoea (primary or secondary), characterized by low gonadotrophins and oestrogen deficiency.
      • Group II ovulation disorders are defined as dysfunctions of the hypothalamic-pituitary ovarian axis. They include conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and hyperprolactinaemic amenorrhoea. About 85% of women with ovulation disorders have a group II ovulation disorder. PCOS is the most commonly encountered type of WHO Group II ovulation disorder and is responsible for the majority of ovulation disorders. Common clinical features include oligo- or amenorrhoea, anovulatory infertility, obesity, and hyperandrogenism. See the CKS topic on Polycystic ovary syndrome for more information.
      • Group III ovulation disorders are caused by ovarian failure and are characterized by high gonadotrophins and hypogonadism and a low oestrogen level. About 4–5% of women with ovulation disorders have a group III ovulation disorder.
    • Other conditions that can cause ovulatory disorders include [Chen and Brzyski, 1999; Balen, 2000; Hamilton-Fairley and Taylor, 2003; Symonds and Symonds, 2004; Monga and Dobbs, 2011]:
      • Thyroid abnormalities — hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism may lead to menstrual disorders and ovulatory dysfunction. See the CKS topics on Hyperthyroidism and Hypothyroidism for more information.
      • Adrenal abnormalities — Cushing's syndrome and congenital adrenal hyperplasia may cause anovulation.
      • Chronic debilitating disease (such as uncontrolled diabetes, cancer, AIDS, end-stage kidney disease, and malabsorption) — may lead to anovulation and amenorrhoea [American Society for Reproductive Medicine, 2004].
  • Other identifiable causes/risk factors of infertility in women include:
    • Tubal, uterine, and cervical factors, including [Cooke, 1996; Hargreave and Mills, 1998; Chambers, 1999; Monga and Dobbs, 2011; Symonds and Symonds, 2004]:
      • Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). See the CKS topic on Pelvic inflammatory disease for more information.
      • Previous sterilization.
      • Endometriosis — tubal distortion and limitation of fimbrial motility due to pelvic adhesions. See the CKS topic on Endometriosis for more information.
      • Cervical mucus defect or dysfunction.
      • Submucosal fibroids — may distort the uterine cavity and impair implantation.
      • Previous cervical surgery — may cause scarring or shortening of the cervix and, rarely, cervical stenosis.
      • Previous pelvic surgery — may cause tubal damage or adhesions.
    • The use of certain drugs, including:
      • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) — there is evidence that NSAIDs may inhibit ovulation [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013]. The effect on fertility is reversed upon withdrawal of NSAID treatment [Aronson, 2006a].
      • Cyclo-oxygenase inhibitors — can have a negative local effect on ovulation [Aronson, 2006a].
      • Spironolactone — can cause infertility and menstrual irregularities. Normal menstruation resumes within 2 months of treatment withdrawal [Aronson, 2006b].
      • Chemotherapy with cytotoxic drugs — can induce ovarian failure, which may be permanent [Janssen and Genta, 2000].
      • Neuroleptic drugs — may cause amenorrhoea and infertility [Aronson, 2006a].
      • Contraceptives — normal fertility returns immediately after stopping the combined oral contraceptive (COC), the progestogen-only pill (POP), the levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS), and the copper intrauterine device (Cu-IUD). After stopping the combined contraceptive patch and the combined vaginal ring, there may be a delay of up to a few months in return to normal fertility. After stopping the progestogen-only injectables, there could be a delay of up to 1 year in the return of normal fertility (menstruation can take several months to return to normal) [FSRH, 2012; FSRH, 2014a; FSRH, 2014b; FSRH, 2015a; FSRH, 2015b].
      • Recreational drugs (such as marijuana and cocaine) — have been associated with impaired ovulatory and tubal function [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013].
      • Other drugs — a case control study reported that women who had ever used thyroid replacement hormones, asthma medication, tranquillizers, or antidepressants had an increased risk of anovulatory infertility [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013].
    • Age — natural female fertility declines with age, and this is more noticeable after 35 years of age [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013; ACOG/ASRM, 2014; BMJ, 2017a].
    • Occupational and environmental factors, including exposure to pesticides, nitrous oxide, metals (lead, cadmium, manganese), solvents, and formaldehyde [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013].
    • Stress (in either the man or the woman) — may affect the couple's relationship and is likely to reduce libido and the frequency of intercourse, which may contribute to infertility [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013].
    • Lifestyle factors, including smoking, obesity, and excessive alcohol consumption [Hughes and Brennan, 1996; Augood et al, 1998; Hull et al, 2000; National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013; ASRM, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Causes of infertility in men
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Identifiable causes (and risk factors) of infertility in men include:  

  • Primary spermatogenic failure (defined as any spermatogenic abnormality caused by a condition other than hypothalamic pituitary disease). Causes may be [EAU, 2016; BMJ, 2017b]:
    • Congenital, for example:
      • Anorchia (absence of testes).
      • Testicular dysgenesis/cryptorchidism.
      • Genetic abnormalities (karyotype, Y-chromosome deletions).
    • Acquired, for example:
      • Trauma.
      • Testicular torsion.
      • Post-inflammatory forms, especially mumps orchitis.
      • Exogenous factors (medications, cytotoxic or anabolic drugs, irradiation, or heat).
      • Systemic diseases (liver cirrhosis, renal failure).
      • Testicular tumour.
      • Varicocele.
      • Surgery that may compromise vascularisation of the testes and lead to testicular atrophy.
    • Idiopathic (unknown aetiology and pathogenesis).
  • Genetic disorders, including:
    • Klinefelter's syndrome with karyotype 47, XXY, which is associated with hypogonadism and disorders of spermatogenesis. This is the most common sex chromosome disorder associated with infertility.
    • Kallmann syndrome, which causes hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism.
    • Small testes.
    • Sterility.
    • Testicular feminization (or androgen insensitivity syndrome), a condition where there is resistance to the virilising effects of androgens, and a child with an XY karyotype appears as a girl. This can be much less complete, and more limited resistance to androgens can lead to poor development of the testes.
  • Obstructive azoospermia (defined as the absence of both spermatozoa and spermatogenic cells in semen and post-ejaculate urine due to bilateral obstruction of the seminal ducts). Causes include [Jungwirth et al, 2012; EAU, 2016]:
    • Ejaculatory duct obstruction:
      • Congenital — prostatic cysts (Mullerian cysts).
      • Acquired — after infection or surgery (such as bladder neck surgery).
    • Vas deferens obstruction:
      • Congenital — absence of the vas deferens.
      • Acquired — after vasectomy or surgery (such as hernia, scrotal surgery).
    • Epididymal obstruction:
      • Congenital — idiopathic epididymal obstruction.
      • Acquired — after infection (such as epididymitis) or surgery (such as epididymal cysts).
  • Varicocele (a common abnormality, found in 11.7% of men with normal semen and 25.4% of men with abnormal semen) [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013; EAU, 2016]. 
    • It may be associated with decreased ipsilateral testicular volume, elevated scrotal temperature and pain, as well as impaired semen quality.
    • The mechanism by which varicoceles might impair fertility and spermatogenesis is unclear [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013; EAU, 2016]. However, there is evidence that semen improvement is usually observed after surgical correction and that varicocelectomy can reverse sperm DNA damage [EAU, 2016].
    • See the rodigy topic on Varicocele for more information.
  • Hypogonadism (characterized by impaired testicular function, which may affect spermatogenesis and/or testosterone synthesis). The aetiological and pathogenetic mechanisms of male hypogonadism can be divided into three main categories [EAU, 2016]:
    • Primary (hypergonadotropic) hypogonadism due to testicular failure.
    • Secondary (hypogonadotropic) hypogonadism caused by insufficient gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and/or gonadotropin (follicle stimulating hormone [FSH] and luteinizing hormone [LH]) secretion.
    • Androgen insensitivity (end-organ resistance).
  • Cryptorchidism (undescended testes).
    • In men with bilateral cryptorchidism,  oligozoospermia can be found in 31% and azoospermia in 42%, and the rate of paternity is 35–53% compared with 89.7% in men with a history of unilateral cryptorchidism and 93.7% in men without cryptorchidism [EAU, 2016].
  • The use of certain drugs, including:
    • Sulfasalazine — can cause infertility and oligospermia. Oral and rectal treatments have the same effects, which are reversible on withdrawal of therapy or by switching to mesalazine [Aronson, 2006c].
    • Androgens and anabolic steroids — can lead to reduction in the volume of the testes and azoospermia or oligospermia because of suppression of gonadotropins [Aronson, 2006c].
    • Chemotherapy with cytotoxic drugs — can induce permanent azoospermia [Janssen and Genta, 2000].
    • Herbal remedies — may cause oligospermia and azoospermia and reduction in testicular size (for example root extracts of Tripterygium wilfordii and gossypol extracted from certain species of Gossypium) [Aronson, 2006c].
  • Other causes, including [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013; EAU, 2016]:
    • Ejaculation disorders or erectile dysfunction — these may be associated with psychologcal factors, hypogonadism, spinal cord disease, and metabolic and vascular conditions (such as diabetes mellitus) [Jungwirth et al, 2012; BMJ, 2017b].
    • Antibodies against spermatozoa — sperm function may be impaired by antisperm antibodies [Jungwirth et al, 2012].
    • Male contraception (vasectomy).
    • Male accessory gland infection (for example urethritis, prostatitis, orchitis, and epididymitis).
    • Germ cell malignancy — men with testicular germ cell tumour have decreased semen quality, even before cancer is diagnosed. 
    • Testicular microcalcification — ultrasound findings of testicular microcalcification are common in men with infertility. The relationship between testicular microcalcification and infertility is unclear but probably relates to dysgenesis of the testes.
    • Exposure to pesticides, X-rays, solvents, paints, or chemicals from smelting or welding.
    • Exposure to heat — there is an association between elevated scrotal temperature and reduced semen quality, but it is still uncertain whether wearing loose-fitting underwear improves fertility [Tiemessen et al, 1996; Munkelwitz and Gilbert, 1998].
    • Lifestyle factors, including [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2013]:
      • Stress, although its association with infertility in men is not clear.
      • Obesity [Kort et al, 2003a; Kort et al, 2003b; ASRM, 2015].
      • Smoking. 
      • Use of recreational drugs (such as cocaine and marijuana) — these can adversely affect the quality of semen.
      • Excessive alcohol intake — this can be detrimental to semen quality, but the effect is reversible and there is no evidence for a causal relationship between moderate alcohol consumption and poor semen quality.
      • Excessive exercising.
      • Excessive travelling that limits optimal coital timing.
  • Semen cryopreservation — damage occurs to cells during cryopreservation and prolonged storage. During freezing, ice crystal formation and cell dehydration can disrupt the cell wall and intracellular organelles; after thawing, sperm morphology, motility, and vitality decrease significantly. Cryopreservation increases the damage done to sperm DNA, and further damage can be caused by contamination of samples with microorganisms and high levels of superoxide radicals.
